title: The Cuban Missile Crisis
key_facts: A 13-day political and military standoff in October 1962 over the installation of Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba.
Considered the moment the Cold War came closest to escalating into a full-scale nuclear war.
The US enacted a naval 'quarantine' (blockade) to prevent further Soviet missile shipments.
Ended with a secret agreement: Soviets removed missiles from Cuba, US pledged not to invade Cuba and removed missiles from Turkey.
causes: Failed US-backed Bay of Pigs invasion (1961) led Castro to seek Soviet protection.
Deployment of US Jupiter missiles in Turkey and Italy, threatening the USSR.
Soviet desire to level the strategic playing field and deter US aggression.
outcome: Establishment of the Moscow–Washington hotline for direct communication between leaders.
Removal of Soviet missiles from Cuba and US missiles from Turkey.

figures.name: John F. Kennedy
figures.significance: Ordered the naval blockade and negotiated the peaceful resolution.

figures.name: Nikita Khrushchev
figures.significance: Ordered the deployment of missiles to Cuba but agreed to withdraw them to avoid war.

figures.name: Fidel Castro
figures.significance: Requested Soviet assistance to defend the Cuban Revolution.

impacts: Highlighted the dangers of nuclear brinkmanship, leading to the Limited Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (1963).
Strengthened the position of Fidel Castro in Cuba but strained relations with the USSR.
Marked a turning point towards 'détente' (easing of tensions) in the Cold War.
sources: Allison, G. (1971). Essence of Decision: Explaining the Cuban Missile Crisis.
Dobbs, M. (2008). One Minute to Midnight: Kennedy, Khrushchev, and Castro on the Brink of Nuclear War.
